Definition: It is expected that you will classify the comment into two classes: toxic and non-toxic. Toxicity is protected like everything that is brutal, unfair or unreasonable, which would make someone look for conversion.

Comment: It is absolutely a free country and I hope it remains so.  But this isn’t about word police or freedom of speech.

Rather than Mr Duke provide a rational reason for his objection to Trudeau’s tolerance, or Mr Kouvalis providing a reasoned challenge to the accuracy of a university professor’s viewpoint, each man descended to that time-honoured schoolyard tactic of hurling epithets.  In the case of Mr Kouvalis, at least, we are speaking of an educated man who would presumably have grown out of short pants by now.

Both the United States and Canada are blessed in that our laws support a free exchange of ideas.

But I don’t think the right to gratuitously insult someone you don’t agree with was what the authors of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms or the First Amendment were thinking about when they took pen in hand.

Comment: This is a stupid poll for several reasons:

First, the total percentages add up to much more than 100%
Second, Trump's disapproval rating of 55% is nothing to cheer about since that's what Obama had when he left office.
Third, even though the disapproval rating of Congress is 66%, you're comparing apples to oranges with Trump (1 person) vs. Congress (535 persons) as Congress has had a tougher and more complex job to do than Trump has had so far. 
Fourth, Congress isn't tweeting at all hours of the day and night or holding pep rallies for its known supporters across America to bolster its image and its egos.
Fifth, Congress has never been popular with the people.

But, most critically, what the Hell does a nebulous concept such as "Approval" really mean?

It is not the same thing as asking someone to judge the competency or effectiveness of a person or body of persons. It's more akin to a popularity contest than any serious inquiry into the actual work being done in Washington.

Comment: There was never much chance that the Bank of Canada would lower the overnight rate in July, but now, with the lower than expected inflation rate update, it is even less likely than it was before. There is a certain irony that the 2016 renewal agreement dethroned the CPIX as the operational guide and preferred core inflation measure starting in January, when the CPIX inflation rate was 1.7% and the Bank’s favoured CPI-common measure, which Leah Schnurr bizarrely calls “the best measure of the economy’s underperformance”, was at 1.4%. Now in May, CPI-common Is still only at 1.3%, while the CPIX inflation rate has sunk like a stone, to 1.3% in March, 1.1% in April and 0.9% in May. It seemed to be a decision whose only rationale was to lower the headline core inflation, and it seems that the Bank failed even in achieving that objective.

Comment: Oh come on, lousy investor.  Start by sticking $25K in your RRSP for a smarter tax move.  Then if you are only taking $100K in salary (or $125K after your RRSP payment), you may be better to take the last $25K out today, pay tax now (because your marginal personal tax rate at that $125-$150 level is not at the highest rates) and just invest the remainder personally.  If you leave $50K of assets in your corp to earn passive investment income, you are paying an initial tax rate of over 50% on investment income in the corp, no matter your personal tax situation, because all passive investment income in a corp is subject to this high rate.  Furthermore, when you take the investment money out of the corp after you retire, your new personal tax from the dividend will eat into your OAS threshold and you may not qualify for OAS.

Comment: Canada escapes being rated lower on the world corruption charts, because paying off a city inspector to keep your substandard restaurant open, or build an addition to your house without it making code/being taxed is relatively rare.

However, it is at the major governance level, that Canada is probably more "middle of the pack"

Canadians look at say Turkey, and see officials being bribed for policy issues (not illegal house additions), and imagine themselves being governed by the mustachioed men they see charged, and conclude that they are glad they live in Canada... 

But the Turks themselves probably don't view those same people as sinisterly (different from being "crooked"). Meanwhile, Canadians see a bunch of people who look like accountants (many are!) being charged with rather obscure offences, and feel that things are great because they believe 'something is being done about it"...and they are not being shaken down by a city inspector for having a fence be 10 cm too tall...

Comment: This article gives bad advice. You don't want to escalate to nuclear option right away, the dispute process takes considerable time, stacked in dealerships favor, and would not necessary result in fixes.

What you need to do is be FIRM with dealer that THIS IS NOT NORMAL and THIS IS NOT OK. Schedule repairs, take their loaner car out and refuse to accept car back without a test drive. If it isn't fixed - insist they redo. Get EVERYTHING in writing and don't accept any verbal promises.

You car is under warranty, dealership is trying to run you out of warranty when it will become your problem. Don't let them. They owe you a working car. If they have to replace transmission - then this is what they will have to do.

Also, insist on side-by-side test drives. Dealer has new cars like yours on the lot. Have you and service person drive both one right after another. This way it is very easy to point out - new car doesn't do this, my car does - therefore my car is broken and has to be fixed.

Comment: Good point.

One thing that appears to have been missed here is that this form of consolidation tends increase - not decrease - administration & expenses.

UAA serves far more education students than UAF.

For this arrangement to work effectively:

* UAA, UAF and UAS will need local Dean-equivalents. The title may change but the job will be the same.

* UAF will need to hire an additional super-Dean (with support staff) or will need to provide additional staff and support to the existing UAF Dean to cover the additional responsibilities.

*  Senior Faculty on all three campuses will need to reallocate their time (especially in the first year) to ensure effective coordination.  If this reallocation reduces research - UA will lose research funding (which includes indirect funding to cover overhead costs).  If this reduces teaching - faculty will need to be hired, or class sizes will increase, or class offerings will be reduced.  if this reduces enrollment, tuition revenue will fall.

Comment: Boozer,

This tax (call it whatever one wants) will become part of the operating costs of each company.  (I wonder if a discriminatory tax is even legal?).  Anyway, each company the tax is assessed to will make a business decision based on its own interests.  Some companies will have the pricing power to pass the whole tax on to the consumer, some will only pass on part of it, and some will not pass any of it on for a while.  But it will raise the company's operating costs and therefore at some point, the price for the product will increase unless demand falls or competition causes a price reduction(s) .

At least with a sales tax it is transparent, one knows they are paying it, and can consciously decide if he or she wants to pay it.   This new tax will be much like Oregon's share of the gasoline tax paid for each gallon of gas.  In 2009 the Oregon legislature raised it from 24 to 30 cents per gallon and it has not been raised since (yet?).  It essentially is a stealth sales tax.

Comment: The author of this piece appears to have a problem with basic arithmetic. 

For example, "use of force by guards increased almost 50 per cent, from 1,000 incidents a year to almost 1,407 last year." This in fact amounts to an increase of 40.7 per cent. Is 40.7 per cent really "almost" equal to 50 per cent? This is sloppy math and lazy reporting.

Furthermore, how much is "almost 1407"? Is it 1406? Or 1403? Or 1327? If the discrepancy in actual figures supplied is proportionate to the discrepancy in reported percentages, that means the actual number of cases of use of force by guards could be as low as 1276 instead of almost 1407.

It is therefore hard to give credence to the reported increase of "almost 60 per cent" in inmate assaults when the "before" figure is omitted and only the "after" figure is supplied.

Who can be bothered to read to the end of an article like this?

Comment: It is a good, and hard, question.   The statute is very clear as to how the PF earnings will be disbursed and after inflation-proofing, half is dedicated to the Dividend.   I agree that it doesn't much matter what previous legislatures and governors have done; it is really a question of Constitutional and statutory interpretation.   The Court has to reconcile the Constitutional prohibition against dedicated funds, the Constitutional requirement of an appropriation to support any State expenditure, and the Governor's Constitutional power to line-item veto. Comment: Many scientists are creationists.  You're acting like science and belief in God or Intelligent Design is incompatible.  No, evolution doesn't explain most of what we see in our world today.  There is no fossil record of evolution happening.  There is no common ancestor of men and apes.  Genetics shows humans have a common female ancestor (mitochondrial DNA). Physics defies evolution by showing that life and the natural world don't gradually get more complex and more orderly over time but rather devolve into disorder and degradation.  There are no vestigial organs like people once thought, like the tailbone, the appendix, the tonsils.  All of these have function.  Darwin's biggest doubt about Evolution was the sudden appearance of all modern forms of animals during the Cambrian Explosion.  He could not offer any explanation.  The coelacanth is a fish that exists today and is not a "missing link".  The archaeopteryx was not a missing link.  It was a regular perching bird.

Comment: No, they would not be cheaper to off-load in Anchorage. Comment: I'm sorry, you are *very* confused.  There are famous geological basins in Wyoming, all right - the Green River basin, or the Powder River basin come to mind - but these are stratigraphic features, not hydrologic ones, per se.

Sheesh, Google it, or go to Wikipedia and find a map, for crying out loud.

From a reference book on the shelf, I'm looking at an erudite article by Speed, Elison, and Heck (1988), entitled 'Phanerozoic Tectonic Evolution of the Great Basin,' and yep, their Figure 1 shows the Great Basin centered on the state of Nevada, stretching from the Sierra Nevada mountains on the west to western Utah on the east (with bits of Oregon and Idaho). 

Most of Wyoming is on the other side of the Continental Divide.  :-/

Yucca Mountain is (a) in Nevada, (b) in the Great Basin, and (c) hydrologically isolated from any drainage reaching the ocean.  Period.  Full stop.

You're entitled to your own opinion, but (to paraphrase the Man), not your own version of geography.  :-/

Comment: No, I don't think that's what the free market does at all. It presumes that this approach will be the most efficient regardless of the conditions. But that may not be true. Sometimes the cost of entering an industry is massive, while the per-unit price you can charge is very low. In those cases it will take decades to make back your investment and show profit. Such a scenario is a natural monopoly - nobody can ever compete with the guy who invested first, since he will make a profit years before they ever can. How then, do you get a market ? Sometimes a business can shove the bulk of the cost of it's product onto unwitting third-parties (we call this externalities). When you don't pay the full price of the product and other are forced to subsidise it against their will - how can you call this "free" ? Polution is an externality. If you PERSONALLY had to get the black lung from coal dust, would you still buy coal power ? As much ? Or would you consider the price too high ?

HART is hiding known risks in building in the civic area that prevent them from putting a price on those four miles.  The HART statement that stopping at Middle St. will lower ridership by 60% is false.

"Our ruling
A widely shared bit of text on the Internet says that "Lincoln was fervently making plans to send all freed slaves to the jungles of Central America once the (Civil War) was over. … The only thing that kept this from happening was his assassination."

This is incorrect on many levels. Even when he was arguing for voluntary colonization during his first two years as president, Lincoln did not envision forced deportations of ex-slaves. Comment: Animals with antlers grow new antlers each year.  While antlers are growing, they are covered with a vascular membrane called "velvet", which provides nourishment to the growing antler.  Once the antler has grown and hardened, the velvet is shed in late summer, which is what is happening in this photo.  The animal will then shed the entire antler in early winter (for male caribou) or early spring (for female caribou).  A new antler will then start growing in the spring.  All antlered animals including deer, moose, elk and caribou have this (although caribou/reindeer is the only species where females have antlers - the rest only males have them).  Antler growth and shedding is regulated by the natural cycling of sex hormones, so it isn't really anything more disturbing than a menstrual cycle.

Comment: Most of the people that I know also have had to share with multiple roommates and no one I know has gone straight to a house either. I actually don't know anyone who still lives with their parents, but those who did (for a limited amount of time), had good reasons.

If you're striking out on your own, expect to be paying around $1700/ month solo here in Vancouver, and it's not easy to get one of those multi-roommate situations because you're dreaming if you think you'll easily find an affordable three bedroom to split. 

We've all tried to be responsible and get ourselves an appropriate education too. I think the educational system needs to take more of a role in helping post-secondary students map education to employment.

Comment: I don't keep Country data by my desk at work. ;) The numbers in that chart are reasonably solid and were useful for making my larger point(s). You cannot just arbitrarily pick a given year and then claim that a law passed shortly thereafter is responsible for following changes. In most of the West the high point for violent crime was the mid-90s, and rates have been trending down ever since. To show a given law had a causal effect you have to show that the rate of decline after that law went into effect made a statistically significant change from the prior trend, and, if the "solution" was a gun access law, that the change persisted.

My whole point is that laws have essentially no documentable effect when you look at the data short or long term. What matters are cultural and demographic factors. The reason you push back before the first significant gun control laws is to see how "violent" a country was when there were no gun controls at all. That gives you a cultural baseline.

Comment: High income earners pay the lions share of all taxes so it is inevitable that anything that reduces taxes will disproportionately benefit higher income earners.

Put another way, if someone is only paying $20/year in total income taxes, the most you can possibly cut their taxes by is $20, or a 100% decrease.  If someone else is paying $10,000/year in taxes and you cut their taxes by $200 they benefited 10 times as much as the first person even though they only saw a 2% decrease in their taxes.

The notion that we can't have any programs that help reduce the tax burden just because those programs might benefit high income earners more is completely misguided and ignorant.

Many policies seem benign or equitable when advanced by

is rarely considered by short term thinkers. Thousands of small business owners hire thousands of employees. Small businesses 
purchase all kinds of manufactured goods from businesses located 
in many jurisdictions. Those subject to the same minimum wage increases now must compete with jurisdictions not affected
by increase costs. What do you think the consequences are?

Comment: It is utterly inexplicable that the Legislature is rushing forward with a tax that the voters overwhelmingly defeated months ago. Oregon needs to make its tax system more progressive, not less, and this new tax is perhaps the most regressive there is, since there is no way to exempt essentials like food and medicine. Low and middle income Oregonians should not pay one cent more in price increases while millionaires pay almost the same income tax rate as someone making less than $20,000 per year.

And throwing in the towel on the corporate income tax makes no sense. Reform it, for heavens sake. Business would likely support reasonable reform.

Our lawmakers need to listen to the very reasonable proposal from the business community of a temporary tax increase to get past the current budget crisis, with future reform discussed when there time to find a solution that is fair to all.

Comment: Sorry to spoil your hindsight theory, but I strategically made that call to minimize QB running prior to the season starting. I was only wrong in thinking Taggart would think the same for the long term good of the team. If we don’t win about 8 games this season, we might see many of those verbal commits to the Ducks #1 ranked recruiting go elsewhere.

Of course you have the QB run by reading when the defense is allowing it, so that might even mean less than once per quarter, and only more if said defense loves getting burned. The idea is to make the defense commit to defending the QB on every down even when he does not run, leaving others more open for big plays, but doing it with the minimum exposure to the only irreplaceable player on the team. Running him at the goal line does not qualify. Taggart is certainly the professional here, but his call was still boneheaded. He is young and will learn. I still have great confidence in him, but that call just cost his team some wins.

Comment: My friends I think we risk missing the point. 

The author engaged on a "lets save democracy" platform. 

Fine. Thats a good idea.

But we are debating the subject as if its simply a matter of deciding which philosophic angle is the most appropriate and asking what has it got to do with us as Canadians. I think the issue is essentially a humanitarian issue at this point as opposed to a political or philosophical one. People are suffering greatly. They can't get food. They cant get medicine. They can't get work. They essentially trade favours to survive as best they can

I was there a few years ago and in the 8 days I was in Caracas the currency devalued about 25%. My generous friends gave me a big stack of currency in case I wanted to buy a cold drink. My host was an electrical engineer who made a living by selling bread on the black market.

I think the least we can do is have a bit of empathy and help make the situation known. It doesn't seem to get much attention on the world stage.

Comment: A neighbor of mine is an elevator technician.  The Ontario government says you need to have two licensed mechanics working for the company before he's allowed to hire one apprentice.  He doesn't have enough business to be able to hire another licensed guy in order to get a helper.  He says they have months worth of backlogged work, but the government won't let them train the next generation.  The Ontario government has set up the apprenticeship programs so that only large companies can hire apprentices and self employed, or small companies can't train anyone.  

The MPP needs to get the apprenticeship laws fixed in Ontario if they want to have qualified technicians (elevator, electrical, plumber, etc.).

Comment: Mr Trudeau and the premiers need to rethink carbon taxes. That doesn't necessarily mean  abandoning them, but it certainly means making them genuinely revenue neutral, i.e. returning ALL the money raised to individuals and corporations through corresponding reductions in income and corporate taxes. That's what economists who originally advanced the idea of carbon taxes had in mind rather than the giant sin tax to add to general revenues to fund pet projects and reduce deficits that Canada's governments seem to think a carbon tax is. Otherwise you simply destroy competitiveness and undermine future prosperity. Mr Trump's victory should reinforce the need for our governments to focus on ensuring competitiveness  and prosperity. The eco movement may haughtily dismiss these concerns as trivial in comparison with saving humanity or the planet or whatever. However, ignoring them is the best way to ensure Canada has its own Trump a few years down the road.

Comment: I took part in that study and so did my children, we have never been sickened by aerial sprays in the forests around our farm. My water tests came back negative for any chemical and so did my soil tests. None, Nada, Zilch. My families urine tests were way, way lower than the national average for 2,4-D and non-detectible for any other chemicals. What I do know is that 2,4-D is widely sold to the general public in lawn care products. The NHANES results for 2,4‐D show that 95 percent of the U.S. population has levels of 2,4‐D in their urine that are below 1.08 μg/g. The average found in the Triangle Lake study was 0.4 μg/g, which is well below the national average.  A Summary of the results for the Triangle lake study can be viewed at Oregon Health Authorities web page: http://public.health.oregon.gov/HealthyEnvironments/TrackingAssessment/EnvironmentalHealthAssessment/Documents/EI%20factsheet_final.pdf

Comment: Wrong. New Hampshire does not, and never did, have a general sales or income tax. Nor can towns levy local sales taxes. NH does have a interest and dividend tax, but it has a high threshold and exemptions.

While we don't have a statewide sales or income tax, most pay property taxes, either directly, or through rents. And many of us pay a sales tax, particularly in smaller communities. So it's not a free ride.

Yep, we get a welfare check every year, but that is likely to end when the stark fiscal enormity of what Alaska faces finally sinks in. So spend it wisely. But it does not, and never has, come "compliments of the oil companies". It's OUR oil, and we are selling it to the oil companies, albeit at fire-sale rates. But that's another story. If the oil companies were giving us "complimentary" cash, other than the pittance that they drip to charities for "goodwill", they would be rightly sued by their stockholders.

Lawmakers doing likewise should get the boot. Stupid, stupid us.

Comment: Here in Richmond condos and townhouses have not appreciated as fast as sf detached houses. But in my Richmond neighbourhood assessments for houses have shot up on average 45%-55%, well beyond that of a condo. 

This is based on land value, as the houses are 45 years old, and their value is for teardown and rebuilding larger mansions.

The city has come up with tax based averages that include condos/townhouses, so anyone with a house will see their property tax increase substantially.  Not to mention that most house owners will lose their $570 "homeowners" discount this year on top of that. And the City is putting up taxes about 3% even if your assessment didn't go up - and everything went up.

Richmond knows the hit will be large this year, and is telling those taxpayers 55+ to defer their property tax until they sell. Imagine.  A city that admits taxation for house owners is so onerous, that their solution is for you to defer payment.

Comment: My older brother was a police officer who died in the line of duty, so I'm not anti-police by any means.  However even he recognized that the "thin blue line" sometimes worked against truth and justice.  Police cameras may not be a perfect tool for assessing officer conduct (or misconduct),  but they are a big step up from simply accepting a police officers assertion that "I felt threatened" as a definitive answer to any and all police use of force with out any further follow-up or accountability.  I agree with the assertion that measures need to be taken to increase perceptions of "police legitimacy".  An officer simply screaming at an unarmed and non-threatening citizen to "comply" before tazing or shooting them seems to be the direction that police training has been going - and it is guaranteed NOT to de-escalate situations or foster feelings of legitimacy among citizens who encounter it.  We need a shift in how police are trained, and to get there we need to SEE what isn't working.

Comment: Bob, the point is that EVERY single solar PV panel goes offline every day at sunset. Every day!

You cannot compare the rare occurrence of two or more nuclear/coal/gas power stations going offline simultaneously with renewable intermittency which in the case of solar is daily, 100% shutdown and wind which is less frequent but can, in a country of our size, be a 100% shutdown across the nation. 

Faced with a threat of 100% lack of renewable energy on windless nights, renewables require a dispatchable backup of sufficient to run the whole country. Other forms of electricity don't require this. In the cases you cited, only two out of hundreds of power stations were offline. With renewables we are talking about 100% of supply going offline.

Comment: Exactly. There are FIVE things that could happen once the referral is made. 

1. The consulting doc may determine that patient isn't qualified for an assisted death, say for lack of capacity. 2. The patient herself could decide against the procedure. 3. The patient could recover, at least temporarily. 4. A natural death could occur. 5. An assisted death is performed.

Comment: Oh Bill gets it all right. He understood what a conflict of interest was when he was a partner in one of the Big 4 accounting firms. Moreover, there was no way indirect ownerships were exempted. All the investments owned by you, your significant other and childen who were financially dependent on you were covered.

Comment: The real elephant in the room is the globally driven law of supply and demand. If local surgeons were to charge the same rates as the Canada Health Act (CHA), or even the higher rates allowed under public motor vehicle insurance and workers’ compensation, the private system would be inundated with medical tourists, and local patients wouldn't stand a chance. 

 I reached his conclusion after searching the internet for less invasive procedures not available under the CHA.  One procedure I looked at was offered on a private basis in Toronto, in a Seattle Clinic two hours by car from my home, and in the UK close to family members.  After taking into account the fee charged by each clinic snd the travel costs involved, the price tag was around $20,000 regardless of the location.

It’s likely the CMA  not forcing their members to treat and charge at CHA rates for fear they’ll simply fold up tent and move across the border.

Comment: I said that politics has nothing to do with the weather, not environmental policy.  Please stop putting words in my mouth.  Nunes certainly likes to use the phrases "extreme environmentalists" and "extreme environmentalism", doesn't he?  That's what's called a "dog whistle" and it's used to cue the loud howling of anti-environmental right-wingers.  

But is Nunes right about any of this?  Without water, California agricultural land doesn't exist.  With empty reservoirs caused by natural climate cycles, probably exacerbated by human-caused global warming, that water has to be pumped from the ground, and those ancient reservoirs, with little to no operating recharge, are sinking fast.  Even with its huge population, far and away the largest user of water is agriculture, not domestic use.

California is going to have to regulate water mining, or lose that limited resource.  That means regulation of business, which Nunes opposes.  So resource abuse is political, not weather or climate.

Comment: Have you been to Tutka Bay?  It is literally the wilderness.  There are no roads.  You have to take a water-taxi there (unless you are fit enough to trek over mountains or kayak across Kachemak Bay), at which point you are likely to pull up to some rocky beach where you have to jump out of the boat (without a ramp) directly onto a small beach, (as there isn't really a dock).  The taxi will arrange to pick you up at a certain time, so if you miss it, you are really in trouble.  Due to time, money, demand, and safety amongst other reasons, one can't necessarily make all areas of the wilderness accessible to the handicapped, unfortunately.  But, for those that are dedicated to a lifetime of fitness, and are adept at the art of outdoor living and wilderness adventure, developments of trails in Tutka Bay are a pleasant reprieve from the overpopulated world around us.  For those who are physically unable to get on the trail, there are several tour boats that can also get someone up close.

Comment: I agree and disagree with your statement.  A dead convict can never commit that crime again.  The guy that rapes and murders is a threat to rape and murder as long as he is alive.   Dead he’s no longer a threat.   That’s not necessarily deterrence to another person committing the crime but it’s absolutely effective at preventing him from ever committing the same crimes.

I disagree with the expense being a good reason to get rid of the death penalty.   It just shifts the most expensive option to the next longest set of appeals.   Appeals will always be exceedingly costly and any defendant that uses their full allotment of appeals for any conviction can run up a staggering bill.   It doesn’t mean we get rid of those penalties too.  It might mean that we take a good solid look at what appeals are available and the timelines for each and look at what is an acceptable number of appeals and avenues for those appeals within the process.

Comment: In regards to being denied therapy: Facilities make money off of the skilled therapy services. For the most part that is where these facilities make their profits from. If this facility was all about money, I do not think the patient was denied therapy. It is my experience that therapy has to end if no progress is made, if a patient refuse therapy for more than 3 consecutive visits, a patient is not demonstrating the ability to learn, or if they have exhausted their 100 days of Medicare coverage. Once Medicare ends coverage, the patient and families have the right to pay out of pocket for therapy. However, again, if the patient does not demonstrate the ability to learn due to advanced dementia, therapy will not be beneficial and the therapist have the right to stop therapy. Doctors can right as many orders as they want...it does not mean the patient will get the therapy. Unless doctor is wanting to pay for it, because Medicare will not.

Comment: I have not gone back to look at the basis for the 2004 newspaper article and instead just went to the HHSC web site where you can find years of financial data including operating results for each facility in the system.  I started with 2007 and looked through 2012 and found the following operating losses for Maui Memorial $14 million in 2007, $37 million in 2008, $42 million in 2009, $22 million in 2010, $32 million in 2011, and $39 million in 2012.  This does not consider huge losses for Kula Hospital and Lanai totaling over $27 million for Kula and about $11 million for Lanai.  

These horrible and unsustainable financial results, which undoubtedly continue to the present (you can check them out on line) are partly due to factors outside the control of hospital management, such as significantly declining Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement rates.  Medicare and Medicaid are typically a hospitals largest payers.  The trend toward lower reimbursements will continue.

Comment: Some of the early people came from the original design firm, Parsons Brinkerhoff. I don't know if that firm is still in business here, many of the employees who worked on HART went to work for HART. The extreme cost overruns imply an original design which was incomplete or inadequate. Why were not some of the problems (utilities, historic sites, routing, plastic pads, and so on) identified during the design phase? Don't the designers have some responsibility for these cost overruns, these potential mistakes? Why does a really big firm like Kiewitt decide not to bid again? They said that they were not getting reimbursed for all the extra work they were having to do. What happened with that? What is the story? I am all for a forensic audit if it is a thorough audit, from the beginning including the design and planning phase. If nothing else, we would understand what went wrong. And, given sea level rise, there are going to be more really really big projects coming up.

Comment: Simple logic.  What incentive is there for Mr. Yates to comply with the river usage rules when there is no realistic chance they will be enforced? Mr. Yates has rejected the implicit social contract requisite of any citizen, and is subsisting in an alternative arrangement where he benefits from loopholes in the river usage rules, while also presumably relying on social programs funded by actual citizens of our community (I say presumably, because Mr. Yates never responded to my question regarding how he manages to survive while living on a river boat).

Comment: Ms. Kobliner makes a number of salient points in her book. The one we take exception to is the idea that children shouldn't know what gifts cost. We believe that gift-giving offers parents the perfect opportunity to discuss and model wise spending, as children are the most interested in learning about money, when they want something! In fact, Ms. Kobliner's description of a teary 10 year old needing to be told that his birthday gift of an ipad cost what several less expensive items might have, gives voice to the idea that lots of good can come from children understanding the full value of a request, before they make it. Ask yourself if you would prefer to be surprise and disappoint your kids, or prepare and delight them when their birthday or another gift-giving opportunity presents itself. We believe that you can teach your kids about money while making their dreams come true. Karen Holland (giftingsense.com)

Comment: I'm not an expert on the proposed rules; however, I think the editor and DeFazio should recognize that the fundamental point is this: Federal flood insurance should not be subsidizing development in flood plains. Let the developers pay the market rate, as well as their fair proportion of any flood mitigation measures (e.g., dams), and the problem will mostly take care of itself.

I also understand, that NMFS has proposed one option which is local development regulations and other actions that result in "no net loss," _not_ a complete ban on development.

Right now, we have an excellent example of a development that would be partially in the flood plain -- the proposed Oakleigh Meadow Co-housing 29-unit condominiums. The proposal would dump tons and tons of rock and fill dirt in the flood plain and cover much of the current meadow with hardscape. The result wouldn't pass NMFS muster because of the impact on listed fish species. Nevertheless, our feckless Planning Division approved it.

Comment: The last time the budget was "balanced" (by the PCs in 2003), it was actually balanced. That is, provincial debt did not go up year-over-year. This budget is not balanced, once all the capital spending that has been shuffled off-budget is included. Debt will increase by $12-13 billion dollars year-over-year. The credit rating agencies are fully aware of these tricks. From Standard and Poor's last credit rating downgrade in 2015: "The stable outlook reflects our expectation that, under our base-case scenario, Ontario will continue to make slow progress in reducing its after-capital deficit in the next two fiscal years..." Note those words: "after-capital deficit." That's what counts. It's still at $12.2 billion, about the average it's been over the years the Liberals have been in power, and higher when one-time "adjustments" and asset sales are taken out.

Comment: My argument is in no way strongest for a single-payer system.  I despise single-payer, for many reasons.  I am free to work for whomever I choose, if they want to hire me.  If I don't like their benefit package, I don't work for them.  I know Hobby Lobby has their religious views mingled with their business management.  If I don't like it, I won't seek employment with them.
A traffic accident can kill me.  Older cars don't have as many airbags.  Should I expect an employer to buy me a late-model car, so I don't get killed in a car wreck, thereby causing them expense to hire my replacement? 
I don't believe in forcing employers to furnish health insurance, then telling them what that insurance must cover.  That is why the cost of insurance increased more dramatically after ACA implementation, than before implementation.  We don't all need the same coverages.  I would rather belong to a pool of low-risk members, than a pool that included high-risk members.  But, that makes me heartless.

Comment: For better or for worse it is almost inevitable that we will have the latter.

Economic cycles are, well, cyclical.  The cycles tend to happen with little change regardless of any policies put in place by any government.  A government might either take the edge off the extremes OR make those extremes worse, but there is little to nothing any government can do to change the nature of economic cycles.

Since WWII the world has worked, with a fair degree of consistency, on about 9 to 10 year cycles, and we're pretty much bang-on that right now.  The economy in 2017 looks an awful lot like it did in 2007.

The election isn't scheduled until late 2019.  It seems HIGHLY likely that we will see a recession before that time.

Comment: How necessary is our federal government? Well, if you live in a coastal city (1/3 of all Americans do) and live near the water, you're government mandated to have flood insurance. The government subsidizes part of the costs. In Houston, some estimates are that 1/2 of all homeowners outside of that area have significant damage to their homes and have NO coverage, at all. They will have to finance major repairs on top of their already existing mortgages (assuming they can qualify: most homeowners borrow to the max possible). In other words, those directed to have coverage will come out okay; those who were left to make the decision will not. Before one says, "well, that's life," think about it: should a government let a significant number of its citizens become homeless? The catastrophic impact would ripple throughout the country: we're a group of individuals but we're all ultimately going to suffer.
Try and reason this through to health care, now...

Comment: "Second: although you'll never hear it (and most Americans would be shocked to think it) America NEEDS China. ..."

As well as the issues associated with gearing up US manufacturing again, there is the issue of consumer prices. For many, many years now people have been used to rock bottom prices that came about for the very reason that countries like China, Mexico, India, Bangladesh, Cambodia and Vietnam have been producing goods made by people earning next to nothing and with no benefits - the uber-capitalist dream! If Trump slams on big tariffs or bans imports then prices will escalate enormously in the US almost overnight and it is the poorer people in the US that will feel the pinch the most - the very people that Trump claims to represent and be working for. A sudden, massive drop in exports to the US could also destabilise countries like Mexico which is already having a lot of troubles.

Comment: Although I disagree with some of the sentiments expressed in this piece by this fine writer, I do agree that Native Alaskans should hold on furiously to their culture, as should all peoples who live in places dominated by foreign culture, because if they don't, those foreign cultures will supplant their own. I am an American of Irish descent, and I appreciate the de-anglicization of place names in Ireland and the regrowth of the Irish language there. But, let's recognize that the domination of one culture over another is not unique to the Americas and not unique to the time of European dominance in world affairs. The Chinese dominated Vietnam for over a century, as they now dominate Tibet. Arabs, Berbers, and Turks dominated much of southern Europe for centuries. There are many, many more examples of the same. In fact, the view that only Europeans and their descendants engage in cultural domination is itself a result of ethnocentrism and its dehumanizing "noble savage" fantasy.

Comment: I agree that corporate welfare should be ended in return for a reduction in corporate taxes. Our tax system has to stay competitive with other countries' tax systems. I also think that personal "tax reduction welfare" should be ended for all but the most needy. Example, elimination of that "sacred cow", the mortgage tax deduction.  Eliminating that  would eventually lead to over-all lower home prices. But, there would be a lot of pain getting there. And that is the problem, nobody wants to incur the economic pain at any level to right the ship. So what do we do? We keep on borrowing to crop up a failing or at best marginal economic system. As long as other countries are willing to loan us money and as long as the Federal Reserve and Treasury can keep up the facade of sound currency, we can continue to stumble along.

I do agree, government (all levels) should be spending money (Which it has been doing on a massive scale during the Obama years.) on prioritized infrastructure.

Comment: After repeatedly railing against professional athletes over what he misperceived as slights to the flag and military, Trump disparaged by joking Wednesday about a bugle call that is part of the armed forces’ time-honored tradition of showing respect for the Stars and Stripes.

“What a nice sound that is. Are they playing that for you or for me?” Trump said smarmingly, before turning to the audience. “They’re playing that in honor of his ratings”
The bugle call was “Retreat,” which signifies the lowering of the American flag on a military installation.
Although Trump attended a military high school, and wraps himself in the flag,remained unmoving and unaware of the music’s meaning.

Comment: Part 1/2
I chose, earlier, to avoid that critique of the article but I'll try to wade into it, now.  The term "dialogical" may refer to:
1. an actual dialog between two sides in opposition attempting to reason to a consensus
2. an Hegelian dialectic wherein everything is circumscribed by time and subject to change
3. a form of logical game with each opponent trading arguments under formalized rules to reach a formal truth
4. a reference to "literary dialog" where ideology supersedes any other important consideration (logic, addressability, culture, etc.)
If the author means 2. the proper term would have been "dialectical" and I can see elements of this in the summary by the writer.  I don't see that 1. or 3. are meant in any specific way, leaving 4. (provided I captured all of the possible meanings).

Comment: That ignores so, so much though.  There are reasons that Lynch was projected by most experts as a 1st or 2nd round pick.  There are reasons that Sloter bounced around and ended up playing at lower-division UNC and went undrafted.

I get that fans only want to go by what they see in a a handful of games (often just preseason games).  But the team has to look at a whole lot more than just that.  It's not that Lynch was a first round pick per se, it's that he was a 1st round pick for a reason - his physical attributes are better, his college experience is better, his potential is better.  

Does that mean he'll automatically be better in real NFL games?... No. Many high draft picks still miss. It just means there's a much better chance he will be good. 

Roughly one UDFA QB per decade turns out to be a very good NFL QB.  Maybe Sloter is the one. But the odds are pretty slim, and a few preseason games against mostly 3's and 4's sure isn't enough alone to tell.

Comment: While I'm sure Mr. Grube strives to produce as objective an investigative report as possible, we should remember that the government is bound by the Constitution. Hawaii is already a very pro-defense state, and the public opinion of the HPD and Prosecutor's Office can only be further degraded by the fact that a majority of news articles only feature criminal defense attorneys' opinions. A thorough explanation of the LEGAL reasons why the government must do or must not do certain things, in context of the news article, would greatly improve the public's understanding of the situation. A majority of the general public probably has no idea what a DAG or DANC plea is, the difference between a crime and an infraction, the difference between an indictment, conviction, and sentence, or the difference between a grand jury and a jury - let alone what each entails.   

The ignorant public is blind to the context, and the criminal defense attorneys are the loudest. Is that responsible reporting?

Comment: And small shops are far less likely to try it - simply because, unlike the big supermarket, the small shopkeeper is part of the community he sells to. There are human bonds between his family and his customers - that is already a deterrent, but it also makes the downsides of getting caught doing bad things much, much worse. It's not just a minor loss of business as those customers who have a choice shop somewhere else until it blows over: it's being ostracised from your community, having your kids bullied at school, having the local mechanic refuse to fix your car.
The less connected businesses are to the communities - the more evil they act, you'll find this consistently. The companies that are most likely to poison the air/water and kill a whole lot of poor people - are the ones whose decision makers live far away in some corporate head office and have never even seen the factory making the poison or visited the town they are dumping in.

Comment: Erin, grade-separated rail is hands-down the most efficient way to move people in terms of space, both in terms of public rights-of-way and parking.  It is also extremely energy efficient.  Ultimately, the impacts of the rail on traffic reduction and CO2 emissions will depend on how many people ride the rail system, the greater the umber of riders, the greater the reduction in both congestion and CO2 emissions. The FEIS did not show a net reduction in traffic congestion with rail in 2030 over 2007's traffic because 1) it projected a total increase of daily trips island wide of about 25% (from 3.2 to 4 million) due to resident and visitor population growth, and 2) because of conservative mode shift estimates having only 1.4% of trips shifting from cars to transit.  The ridership projections in the FEIS were conservative and based solely on the addition of the rail, and excluded all other policies that can impact mode choice.

Comment: There was no widespread dissemination of vernacular Bibles on the continent and no English translation approved by the RC church in England until the Counter-Reformation. Yes, the editions you mention existed but in a very restricted circle. Even when vernacular editions existed in various tongues, Catholics often needed the local bishop's permission to possess one, and woe betide those who failed to obtain it.

The Reformation changed that. Now anyone with literacy (and some money) could find a Bible in their own language. No longer did scripture remain the closely held possession of Catholic prelates and clergy.

Comment: The case may go to the US Supreme Court on the issue of the imposition of the temporary stopping of Trump's ban until a hearing on the constitutionality and legality of the ban at the District court level. But the case may be sent back to the District Court for action on the merits of the case against the ban. It is possible that the Supreme Court will say enough about the constitutionality issue to offer strong guidance on the law to the district court(s), but the hearings at the district courts where the challenges to the law are heard will decide the merits of the case against the ban. If the government loses, there could be another appeal to the Circuit Court of Appeals and then another appeal to the US Supreme Court as well.

Comment: There isn't an earnings gap study anywhere in the world that doesn't see significant impacts on women's lifetime earnings relative to men due to the time invested in child care. Pretty much every industry sees higher female than male attrition in their 20s and 30s, and lower female than male engagement at those same ages. Even industries dominated by women, like nursing, see more attrition from the field at those ages. It's not a hard argument to make that sharing child care impacts more evenly between mothers and fathers would even out lifetime earnings a bit.

But ... ultimately whose responsibility is that? Government policy can incent but the end decision on the split is in the hands of those parents, and many polls show big gaps between the percentage of women vs. men who want to leave work to raise kids.

"If both sexes are equally likely to take time off post-pregnancy, there’s no reason to discriminate on any grounds."

Well, except against those planning families, perhaps.

Comment: (1/2) Oh, my dear Veritas 101, your post displays some pretty astonishing logic errors.  First, if the children had been my own, I would have (a) been grateful that they survived their lack of bear-sense, and (b) used it as a teachable moment regarding sharing space with wildlife.  Side note:  my kids were raised in the Bush and were taught from a young age how to be safe when in bear country.  Next, you make the leap of suggesting that those of us who advocate using good bear-sense do not take the incident seriously.  Again, this is a faulty assumption.  As Mr. Sinnott points out, this was a defensive action by a sow protecting her cubs.  It is that risk that prompts so many of us to urge all people choosing to use our amazing trail systems to be vigilant, attentive to surroundings, and alert.  Having raised teens and taught hundreds more, I suspect that these four were not applying those basic behaviors.  That doesn't make the kids bad, just foolish.

Comment: Tactics of Rebuttal: The 4D Approach

Russia’s narrative can be viewed as an offensive weapon.  When it comes to defending Russia, different tactics are used. They can be summed up in four words: dismiss, distort, distract, dismay.

Dismiss: The first Russian approach to negative reporting or comment is to dismiss it, either by denying the allegations on the ground, or denigrating the one who makes them.

Distort: Russian officials and media have also developed a strong tendency to distort information to serve their overall narrative.

Distract: A further tool in Russia’s information arsenal is distraction: turning attention away from the activities of Russia and its allies by launching accusations elsewhere.

Dismay: The final key tool in Russia’s communications arsenal is to spread dismay, by warning that moves which Russia opposes will have disastrous consequences for those planning them.

It’s a brand of information warfare, known as dezinformatsiya.

Comment: FACT #6: FOR INFANTS, FLUORIDATED WATER PROVIDES NO BENEFITS, ONLY RISKS
Up until the 1990s, health authorities advised parents to give fluoride to newborn babies. This is no longer the case. Today, the Institute of Medicine recommends that babies consume a minuscule 10 micrograms of fluoride per day.[28] This is roughly the equivalent of what babies ingest from breast milk, which contains virtually no fluoride.[29]

Infants who consume formula made with fluoridated tap water consume up to 700 to 1,200 micrograms of fluoride, or about 100 times more than the recommended amount. According to the CDC, these early spikes of fluoride exposure during infancy provide no known advantage to teeth.[30] These spikes can, however, produce harm.

Comment: "By modifying your vehicle, you've changed the range. You must admit there is a dramatic difference in soot/smoke produced by your truck under low-boost lugging compared to stock truck?"

I'd agree with that.

However, "low boost lugging" isn't a range in which the vehicle is designed/intended to operate, modified or not. Sure, it's *capable* of being run that way, but it's still an exception to normal operation. (EGTs go up dramatically; turbos, especially, do not like sustained 1600°F.)

When my truck does it, it's almost always operator error (e.g. going 60MPH, need to merge into 75MPH traffic, in 6th gear instead of 5th). It's never intentional.

Sure, cite the guy who intentionally rolls coal every time he pulls away from an intersection and soots tailgaters. But don't "ban" the hardware. And don't demonize the guy who occasionally and unintentionally makes a cloud - especially if he's producing less emissions (and getting better MPG) than stock while cruising at 70MPH.

Comment: "The principal benefit of incorporation for a physician is to take advantage of the lifetime capital gains exemption, which can shelter up to $835,716 in lifetime income for each shareholder ..."

This is a completely bogus statement.  

The lifetime capital gains exemption (LCGE) only applies to situations where the corporation owner sells the shares of an operating company under very particular circumstances.  Doctors rarely have practices that they can sell, but if they can sell them, only an uninformed buyer purchases shares, and even if a buyer will purchase shares, they pay less for them compared with buying assets.  Plus, one of the conditions that bumps the corporation from eligibility for the LCGE is having too many assets on hand relative to the corporations operating needs - if the corporation is a savings vehicle (which most are), they don't qualify.

So toss that statement right out the window - it makes no sense!

Comment: Nothing beats a set of good quality studded winter tires on a vehicle but I admit, for some people they are overkill.  For those that only occasionally need to drive in heavy snow, the alternative is to run M/S tires and then when conditions deteriorate, like they can on the Coquihalla, then install a set of cable chains on the drive wheels.  Cable chains are lightweight, easy to put on, and will allow you to drive at 50km/hr on snow covered roads.  Carry the chains in the trunk along with a pair of winter gloves and a piece of plastic to lie on.  Practice putting the chains on in your driveway before you leave.  Get them as tight as possible and then tighten them again after a km or two.  Having a couple of bungee cords to stretch across the face of the wheel to pull the cables tight helps also.  I have a 4x4 with studded winter tires but I still carry chains with me when driving in the mountains.  I use heavy duty v-bar chains off road and cable chains on the highway.

Comment: No unfortunately, it's actually completely legal:

http://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/travel/united-airlines-chaos-reveals-truth-behind-overbooking-flights/article34659172/

"When you board a flight, you tacitly agree to what’s called the “tariff” in Canada and “conditions of carriage” in the United States, legal documents (Air Canada’s is 83 pages long, WestJet’s about 50) that outline what an airline owes its customers, and how pasengers should be treated.

 Even so, the code of conduct is no assurance that you won’t show up for your fully paid flight and be told that you do not, in fact, have a seat.

It’s what's known in the industry as “overbooking,” and it’s particular to airlines. According to most tariffs and conditions of carriage, the airline reserves the right to pluck you out of your seat if they’ve sold it twice, which is perfectly legal, even in Canada."

Comment: I'm from NS and lived in Halifax for five year during school. It's one of my favourite places. I don't want to see it wrecked by an inflationary mess of 50,000 Amazon employees. To be clear, Amazon's "HQ2" will emphatically not be in Halifax, but the very idea is farcical. Yes, Halifax and Nova Scotia need more well-paying jobs, but these numbers would overwhelm the region to the detriment of livability, to say nothing of cost of living or infrastructure. What holds the province back is more the parochial attitudes of its politicians, not to mention things like Savage's laughable comparisons to Seattle. Halifax is about 400,000 people generously spread around the peninsula, Dartmouth and suburbs around the basin, situated in a province with less than a million people. Seattle may have only 700,000 in the city proper, but the metro region has closer to 4 million. It's bigger than Vancouver and closer to Montreal in size.

Comment: .

Lots of angst here about "delivery charges".

The delivery cost to my cottage is usually about four times the cost of the electricity itself.

That's because the actual costs to deliver electricity to remote areas is so high.

If there are 100 residences on a line that delivers electricity 20 kilometres through bush, wouldn't it seem reasonable that the delivery cost is much higher than for 1000 residences on a five kilometre line in a developed area?

In addition, hydro lines through wooded areas require frequent repairs for downed lines and regular maintenance to cut back growth.

Remote delivery charges are higher because remote delivery is costlier.

Why would anyone think that they shouldn't pay the true cost to get their electricity to them?

Why would anyone think that everyone else should subsidize their delivery costs?

.

Comment: If the 6% IAP Contribution is directed to the Pension plan, and if the collective bargaining language requires the employer to provide a 6% pay increase.  Making this change would actually cost more than the current plan.

For example, if an employee is currently paid $1,000 a month the employer send $76.50 (7.65%) to FICA, about $220 (22%) to PERs pension and $60 (6%) to the IAP, so the employee costs the employer $1,357 for the month.  If the IAP contribution is redirected and the employee has to provide a 6% pay increase, the employee's month pay becomes $1,060, $81 (7.65%) goes to FICA, $297 (28%) goes to PERS pension, $0 goes to the IAP and the employee now costs the employer $1,438 for the month, an increase of $81.

Unless the employer's resource have increased, this change results in less services being able to be provided by the employer.

Comment: There were several English dictionaries before Samuel Johnson produced his. But Johnson's dictionary was the first really successful one. Similarly, Luther's translation is to German bibles what the King James is to English bibles, the generally accepted standard. Is Luther's bible perfect? Of course not. While his Greek was good, and he had a decent Koine Greek NT in Erasmus'  Textus Receptus, his Hebrew was non-existent and the OT is not up to the standard of his NT. 

Where Luther's version shone was in the excellence of his German. It is literate and written in the vernacular of his day. It went a long way towards defining Hochdeutsch, and standardized German spelling.

Comment: Mefloquine has been approved for use since the 80s. The article is very misleading when it says that Canadian soldiers in Somalia used it as a clinical trial.

I lived in East Africa in the 90s and took Meflaquine without fail for two years with no side effects whatsoever. I knew about the possible side effects (they're written on the bottle), but Meflaquine was the only anti-malarial that is effective against cerebral malaria, which was rampant where I was living.

Malaria is incredibly pervasive and deadly - over a million people die of it every year. The potential side effects are worth the risk.

As for Canadian soldiers, my take is that Meflaquine was used as an excuse for egregious behavior in Somalia, and the urban myth has dragged on.

Comment: I didn't think it was there.....I can't imagine anyone signing a four year contract which, in fact, was not a four year contract.  If a contract allows the employer to terminate a contract with only a month's notice and NO CAUSE, it is really a month to month contract.....not a four year contract.  We have apartments and rent month to month or with a year's lease.  Month to month allows a "no cause" termination of the rental agreement.  The year's lease does not allow such a "no cause" termination.  If Mr. Walls signed a contract thinking it was four years in length, but in fact it was month to month, he was, IMO, badly duped. Comment: There is no such thing as "freedom from religion," any more than there's freedom from politics, social mores or any other kind of belief. No one has the right to be insulated or isolated from concepts, thoughts and beliefs that they don't accept.

Nor is there a general freedom from having religious beliefs imposed on you. For example, if my religious belief is that I must shun those who don't follow my religion,  I can impose that belief on others. Or if my religious belief is that I must stand on a street corner and offer religious materials to passersby, no one may hinder me in that belief either. Likewise, my church might restrict its place of worship to those who follow the religion. All others have that exclusion imposed on them, and can do nothing about it.

In short, you may impose your beliefs on others as long as you do so lawfully.

Comment: Let's be realistic here. If the Government of Ontario did not offer all of these Feed in Tariffs, NONE of these projects would have been built because on their own they did not and continue not to make financial sense. Why not invest in a project that pays even if it is not producing anything? There's no downside risk on that baby.
In Ontario's case, all that investment in renewables has lead to a maximum 5% contribution to the total needs of the province. Sure, its easy to point to success stories elsewhere. They have the right combination of geography and/or  population density. Ontario has no Iowa to Oklahoma corridor where we can expect wind power of 400-500 w/m2 on a sustained basis. The right place to build windmills in Ontario is in the area of Hudson/James Bay between York Factory and Akimiski Island - about 100 km offshore. That's the only place in Ontario where wind power makes sense. Everything else is just show.

Comment: "a mandate that most individuals get health insurance"
*
It is a little more complex.  
i) it was a mandate that working individuals above a certain income get health insurance, OR pay a heavy fine instead.  
ii) "most" is correct but perhaps a little misleading.  For example, in California more than 30% get health care/insurance for free.  They do not have to pay for it and do not get fined.
iii) The health insurance that many buy because they are forced to is next to useless because it only pays 60% and has a huge deductible.  That is all many of those who are paying can afford.  
iv) The people who are getting it for free have problems too.  The repayment schedule is so low that many doctor's will not take them.
*
It's a GA mess.

Comment: I read your link.  As a mental health practitioner I think the article you cite fails to mention that in teenagers, the executive centers of the brain are not fully functional and won't be until the mid twenties.  The military seems to understand this on some intuitive level because they take teenagers and put them in infantry and other front line killing situations.  We can see this historically for millennia and recently with even younger children in the developing world.  We really need to understand that teenage brains are not yet adult brains and decisions we think teens should be capable of making aren't a given.  

I will most certainly watch this series to make up my own mind, but the fact it's been produced is a positive thing....whether that makes us comfortable or not.
